Hi @auspham - can you please clarify why we would need to set the `ptf_imagetag` in the `testbed.yaml`? Specifying `-e ptf_imagetag=tagname` to `add-topo`, `redploy-topo`, `renumber-topo` and in this case `refresh-dut` should be able to set the desired tag for a testbed. And this modification won't let us override the value from command-line.

Hi @opcoder0, this is just another way to update the image and would be more convient if the user can just add-topo. We're currently having the specify different ixia image version for different testbed but sharing the same code base. It would be convenient to have this defined already in testbed.yaml

This would not override the `-e` extra parameters, since the extra parameter will have the highest precedence according to ansible docs: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/general_precedence.html#using-e-extra-variables-at-the-command-line:~:text=itself%2C%20have%20the-,highest%20precedence,-among%20variables%20and

I also tested this as well and can confirm that providing extra parameter with `-e ptf_imagetag=tagname` would overwrite the image tag and discard the `ptf_imagetag` set in testbed.yaml

> Hi @opcoder0, this is just another way to update the image and would be more convient if the user can just add-topo. We're currently having the specify different ixia image version for different testbed but sharing the same code base. It would be convenient to have this defined already in testbed.yaml
> 
> This would not override the `-e` extra parameters, since the extra parameter will have the highest precedence according to ansible docs: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/general_precedence.html#using-e-extra-variables-at-the-command-line:~:text=itself%2C%20have%20the-,highest%20precedence,-among%20variables%20and
> 
> I also tested this as well and can confirm that providing extra parameter with `-e ptf_imagetag=tagname` would overwrite the image tag and discard the `ptf_imagetag` set in testbed.yaml

Thank you @auspham for the clarification. LGTM

@rraghav-cisco , @sdszhang:
I think we should not incorporate vendor-specific fixes in the infra code. If at all, we should add vendor-specific check and leave original code for the rest of the platforms. Down-side to that is - it might just become too much to debug in case of failures and over-burden of platform-specific if-then-else checks.

Example:
In traffic-generation.py:
```
if <vendor_specific_platform_check>:
 ipv4.dst.value = static_routes_cisco_8000(base_flow_config["rx_port_config"].ip)
else:
 ipv4.dst.value = base_flow_config["rx_port_config"].ip
 ```
This is just a proposal and needs to be discussed with wider audience.

> @rraghav-cisco , @sdszhang: I think we should not incorporate vendor-specific fixes in the infra code. If at all, we should add vendor-specific check and leave original code for the rest of the platforms. Down-side to that is - it might just become too much to debug in case of failures and over-burden of platform-specific if-then-else checks.
> 
> Example: In traffic-generation.py:
> 
> ```
> if <vendor_specific_platform_check>:
> ipv4.dst.value = static_routes_cisco_8000(base_flow_config["rx_port_config"].ip)
> else:
> ipv4.dst.value = base_flow_config["rx_port_config"].ip
> ```
> 
> This is just a proposal and needs to be discussed with wider audience.

@amitpawar12 , I started like that only, but after repeating the above if-else multiple times, I moved it into the function and left a single line code instead. Made the changes smaller.

Hi @saiarcot895 IN the PR, I see you have such change:
 output = duthost.command(f"systemctl show {systemd_service} --timestamp unix -P ExecMainStartTimestamp")
 return datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp(int(output['stdout'][1:])) > start_time

When the timezone on the DUT is not UTC, we may have failure. Now we get the failure in our regression due to we are not using the UTC timezone.

> Hi @saiarcot895 IN the PR, I see you have such change: output = duthost.command(f"systemctl show {systemd_service} --timestamp unix -P ExecMainStartTimestamp") return datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp(int(output['stdout'][1:])) > start_time

Hi @congh-nvidia, can you help me understand why the upper_case/lower_case can impact traffic balancing?

> Hi @congh-nvidia, can you help me understand why the upper_case/lower_case can impact traffic balancing?

Hi @bingwang-ms , it doesn't affect balancing. The same IPv6 address with different cases in config will be considered as different entries by sonic and lead to failure in creating/removing rif. This is a known issue in SONiC.
And the generic hash test changes the default configuration when testing the layer2 keys, which has actions to remove/add IPv6 address.
The symptom of this failure is packet loss(actually the system crashes and restarts), not in the balancing check.

Could you help me understand why the test starts failing on physical testbed as well? Is there any recent change in arp_responder?

> Could you help me understand why the test starts failing on physical testbed as well? Is there any recent change in arp_responder?

There was a recent change that changes the last 18 bytes of the responding arp packet from the ferret server.
This causes packet mismatches in the PTF test when checking the full default length of 60 bytes.

 https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/commit/8ea0d3e0f65bf0fd2ce8ce18dfe8deccfa68986b#diff-51cd7fcc6e0d30d81b0254bafba60849e0e26e9f308e5779d1f57f3d46a279beR177

Truncating the check to only 42 bytes (removing 18 bytes) would account for the recent 18 byte change in the return packet.

@johevans , could you please comment on the possible cause of RQP (PRP_UC_DISCARD_PACKETS) error in above test?

It was seen that the RQP error no longer occurs when packet-cell-packing (PCP) is disabled. In this test we are using small packets (112B) so PCP will be active. Also, the error is does not occur if the drain procedure sends one packet at a time. This effectively disables PCP, since a cell that is eligible to be packed is not held indefinitely. IIRC, there is a timeout, which is much smaller than the time between packets sent one at a time.

Therefore, PCP is the prime suspect. However, it is a conundrum as to why. It could be explained by a time stamp check on Egress - that is, if cells were held over for a long time. However, no cells should be held over, since the IPT will always send the entire packet. Perhaps there is an additional latency check at Egress for PCP packets? The root cause is still under investigation.

The next step is to find which error conditions listed in RQP_CELL_DECODER_DEBUG_COUNTERS are triggered. (Each error can be disabled individually.)

Thanks @johevans @ansrajpu-git . One thing is still puzzling me how is his impacting port leakout value ?

We do not know the actual error yet, (as seen in the RQP debug mask register mentioned above). However, here are two hypotheses:

1) Perhaps sometimes we have less credits than expected and the drain procedure sends one more packet than we can dequeue. When the first packet of the actual test is sent, perhaps it is packed with this old packet.

2) Perhaps an RQP error seen during the drain procedure affects later packets. That is, it disrupts re-assembly for later packets.

Another clue is that the discrepancy is seen in qos-1. Perhaps a qos-1 packet is the last packet sent by the drain procedure? That would point to hypothesis 1.
